{{more footnotes|date=November 2012}} {{Infobox person | name = Abigail Hopper Gibbons | image = <!-- filename only, no "File:" or "Image:" prefix, and no enclosing [[brackets]] --> | alt = <!-- descriptive text for use by speech synthesis (text-to-speech) software --> | caption = | birth_name = <!-- only use if different from name --> | birth_date = {{Birth date|1801|12|7}} | birth_place = [[Philadelphia, Pennsylvania]] | death_date = {{Death date and age|1893|1|16|1801|12|7}} | death_place = [[New York City]], New York | resting_place = [[Green-Wood Cemetery]] in [[Brooklyn, New York]] | nationality = American | other_names = Abby | occupation = schoolteacher | years_active = | known_for = abolitionism, social activism, prison reformation | mother = Sarah Tatum Hopper | father = [[Isaac Hopper]] | spouse = James Sloan Gibbons (m. 1833) | children = William, Sarah Hopper, Julia, Lucy, Isaac, James | notable_works = }} '''Abigail Hopper Gibbons''', neé '''Abigail Hopper''' (December 7, 1801 – January 16, 1893) was an American [[Abolitionism in the United States|abolitionist]], schoolteacher, and social welfare activist. She assisted in founding and led several nationally known societies for social reform during and following the [[American Civil War|Civil War]].
She grew up in [[Philadelphia]] in a [[Religious Society of Friends|Quaker]] family; her father, [[Isaac Hopper]], opposed slavery and aided fugitive [[slavery|slave]]s. She grew to share her father's beliefs and spent much of her life working for social reform in several fields. In 1841, the New York Monthly Meeting disowned Gibbons' father and husband for their anti-slavery writing. Abigail Gibbons resigned the following year, also removing her minor children.<ref name="Swarthmore">"[http://www.swarthmore.edu/Library/friends/ead/5174ahgi.xml Abby Hopper Gibbons Papers, 1824-1992: Background Notes"], 1996, Friends Historical Library of Swarthmore College, Retrieved 11 March 2012.</ref>
Gibbons was prominent during and after the American Civil War, when her work in [[Philadelphia, Pennsylvania]]; [[Washington, D.C.]]; and [[New York City]], New York included [[civil rights]] and education for blacks, [[prison reform]] for women, medical care for Union officers during the war, aid to veterans returning from the war, to help them find work; and [[Welfare (financial aid)|welfare]]. Because she was a known abolitionist, her house was among those attacked and destroyed during the [[New York City draft riots]] of July 1863.<ref name=CBSNews-UndergroundRR-2017>{{cite news|last1=Silverman|first1=Alex|title=Chelsea Neighbors Declare Victory In Fight To Preserve Manhattan’s Last Underground Railroad Stop|url=http://newyork.cbslocal.com/2017/05/24/chelsea-underground-railroad-stop/|work=[[CBS News]]|date=24 May 2017}}</ref>
==Early Life and Career== Abigail Hopper was born in Philadelphia in 1801, the third of ten children. She was informally called Abby.<ref>Gibbons, Sarah Emerson: ''The Life of Abby Hopper Gibbons as Told Chiefly Through Her Correspondence'' (1896)</ref> Both of her parents were proud abolitionists. Her father, [[Isaac Tatem Hopper]], was of the [[Elias Hicks|Hicks]]ite branch of Quakers. Her mother, Sarah Tatum Hopper, became a recommended minister for the Society of Friends <ref> http://asp6new.alexanderstreet.com/was2/was2.object.details.aspx?dorpid=1000640987 </ref> and oversaw schools for black children along with a committee.<ref>https://books.google.com/books?hl=en&lr=&id=DXysBwAAQBAJ&oi=fnd&pg=PA253&dq=%22abigail+hopper%22&ots=BIpn4EsVgH&sig=ZP5xanylmLqPUAUzASckAUk9CrE#v=onepage&q=%22abigail%20hopper%22&f=false</ref>
Her father became an active and leading member of The [[Pennsylvania Abolition Society]]. He often directly confronted slave kidnappers, who frequented Philadelphia and sometimes kidnapped [[free people of color|free blacks]] for sale into slavery, as well as captured fugitive slaves to gain bounties. Called upon to protect the rights of African Americans, Isaac Hopper and his wife garnered a reputation as friends and advisers of the "oppressed race" in all emergencies. The Hoppers also sheltered many poor Quakers in their house, despite their own family's large size and the father's unstable financial status. The children early on were called to aid others.{{Citation needed|date=March 2013}}
Both of Hopper's parents came from historically Quaker families and passed Quaker beliefs down to their children. Hopper further practiced these beliefs by attending Friends' schools growing up. In 1821, she also founded a school that practiced Quaker beliefs. Later, in 1830, Hopper moved to [[New York City|New York]] and became a teacher at a Quaker school. <ref> https://www.britannica.com/biography/Abigail-Hopper-Gibbons </ref>
Abigail grew up to share her parents' abolitionist sentiments. She worked with well-known abolitionists of her time, including [[Lydia Maria Child]], [[Sarah Moore Grimké]], [[William Lloyd Garrison]], and [[Theodore Dwight Weld]]. <ref>http://asp6new.alexanderstreet.com/was2/was2.object.details.aspx?dorpid=1000640987</ref> Though it was a predominantly black organization, Hopper joined the Manhattan Anti-Slavery Society in 1841. This organization protested all-white memberships of other societies, including the Ladies' New York City Anti-Slavery Society. <ref>https://books.google.com/books?hl=en&lr=&id=DXysBwAAQBAJ&oi=fnd&pg=PA253&dq=%22abigail+hopper%22&ots=BIpn4EsVgH&sig=ZP5xanylmLqPUAUzASckAUk9CrE#v=onepage&q=%22abigail%20hopper%22&f=false</ref>
==Marriage and Family== On February 14, 1833, Abigail Hopper married James Sloan Gibbons, a fellow Hicksite Quaker from New York, who was also an ardent abolitionist. In 1836, the couple moved to New York City, where they had six children -- William, Sarah, Julia, Lucy, Isaac, and James. Two of their sons, Isaac and James, died in infancy.<ref> http://asp6new.alexanderstreet.com/was2/was2.object.details.aspx?dorpid=1000640987 </ref> A third died suddenly after an accident while he was attending [[Harvard University]]. Their daughters included Sarah Emerson Gibbons, who published an edited collection of her mother's letters and a short biography of her, and Lucy Gibbons (who married a Mr. Morse and had a family).<ref name="Admin">[http://www.swarthmore.edu/Library/friends/ead/5174ahgi.xml Abby Hopper Gibbons Papers, 1824-1992: Administrative and Other Descriptive Information"], Friends Historical Library of Swarthmore College, 1996, Retrieved 28 November 2012</ref>
==Quaker Rejection== Some Quaker yearly meetings divided due to influences from Deism, as well as differences between urban and rural members. In 1841, the New York Monthly Meeting, which was dominated by Hicksites, disowned [[Isaac Hopper]], her father, and James Sloan Gibbons, her husband, for their writing and other activities against slavery. The following year Abigail Hopper Gibbons resigned from the Meeting in protest, also removing her and James' four minor children. She and her family maintained Quaker practices and faith but did not rejoin the Meeting.<ref name="Swarthmore"/>
==Women's Prison Association== Abigail Hopper Gibbons became involved in a variety of social reform movements. For twelve years in New York, she was also president of a German industrial school for street children. In 1845, she and her father founded the [[Women's Prison Association]] (WPA) of New York City. She lobbied the city government for improvements in the city's prisons, advocated the hiring of police matrons, and urged the construction of separate prisons for women, as they were housed in the same facilities as men. She frequently visited the various prisons in and about New York.
Under her leadership, in 1853 the [[Women's Prison Association]] separated from its parent, the Prison Association, and Gibbons obtained a New York State charter for her group. She led an aggressive program of legislative lobbying at the city and state level to improve prison conditions for women. She protested jail overcrowding and demanded that women prisoners be searched only by female matrons. She also believed that it would be beneficial for her proposed female prisons to be run by women as well. <ref>https://books.google.com/books?hl=en&lr=&id=upLgBQAAQBAJ&oi=fnd&pg=PP1&dq=%22abigail+hopper%22&ots=VHNQAixeVw&sig=zb5dfwvFubytNlNlpLIAVPoPvSw#v=onepage&q=%22abigail%20hopper%22&f=false</ref>
==Civil War== With the outbreak of the [[American Civil War]], Gibbons knew that nurses would be needed to care for the wounded. The [[United States Sanitary Commission]] was established in 1861, shortly after the Civil War began, to recruit nurses and to provide adequate medical care to the Union wounded. It would undertake numerous fundraising efforts to raise money for these purposes. When the Commission set up a training base at [[Davids' Island (New York)|David's Island Hospital]] in New York, Gibbons was among the trainees. She worked closely with contraband slaves who supported the Union's effort. These formerly enslaved people had often escaped from the South and sought refuge with the Union. Hopper helped them with childbirth and any other familial issues. She also collected donations from those in the North and gave them to the contraband slaves. Additionally, she used her wages to help pay for medical expenses encountered by patients who resided in a contraband camp. <ref>https://books.google.com/books?hl=en&lr=&id=DXysBwAAQBAJ&oi=fnd&pg=PA253&dq=%22abigail+hopper%22&ots=BIpn4EsVgH&sig=ZP5xanylmLqPUAUzASckAUk9CrE#v=onepage&q=%22abigail%20hopper%22&f=false</ref>
She traveled to Washington D.C., to help at the Washington Office Hospital, where she aided wounded officers and distributed supplies. She also helped to establish two field hospitals in Virginia. At [[Point Lookout, Maryland]], the federal government took over a hotel and 100 guest cottages, converting them into a hospital complex with accommodations for 1500 soldiers. It was named Hammond General Hospital. Gibbons vied with [[Dorothea Dix]], the Union Superintendent of Nurses, for control of the hospital. She finally gained an appointment as its head matron. In 1863 she left the facility after the hospital was adapted for use as the [[Point Lookout Confederate Prison]].{{Citation needed|date=October 2009}}
In New York City, social tensions increased with the imposition of the draft. Many Irish immigrant working men did not support the war or abolition of slavery; they resented being drafted when wealthier men could pay for substitutes to take their places. With the [[Emancipation Proclamation]] of 1863, they feared more job competition by blacks and the loss of work or being driven to lower wages. During the [[New York Draft Riots]], ethnic Irish led mob attacks against individual blacks, their residences and businesses, as well as the [[Colored Orphan Asylum]] in the largest civil insurrection in United States history.<ref>Foner, E. (1988). ''Reconstruction: America's Unfinished Revolution, 1863-1877'', The New American Nation series'', pp. 32-33, New York: Harper & Row</ref> They also attacked residences of known white abolitionists and prominent Republicans. On Tuesday, July 14, 1863, the Gibbons' Manhattan home at 19 Lamartine Place<ref>Save Lamartine Place [http://savelamartineblockschelseaw29w30nyc.blogspot.com/2007/10/lamartine-blocks-w29th-and-w30th.html website]</ref> (now 339 West 29th Street) was burned and destroyed by rioters.<ref>McCague, James (1968). ''The Second Rebellion: The New York City Draft Riots of 1863'', pp. 124-125. New York: Dial Press.<!-- isbn needed --></ref><ref>Bernstein, Iver (1990). ''The New York City Draft Riots: Their Significance for American Society and Politics in the Age of the Civil War''. Oxford University Press.</ref><!-- isbn needed -->
==Post-war== Following the war, Gibbons founded the Labor and Aid Society, which aided returning veterans find work. To further her mission with women prisoners, she co-founded The Isaac T. Hopper Home, named for her father. It assisted former women prisoners to integrate into society after their release.<ref name="Swarthmore"/> As a result of her working on notable social reform movements, Gibbons corresponded with other nationally prominent leaders, including [[Theodore Roosevelt]], [[Lydia Maria Child]], and [[Joseph H. Choate]].<ref name="Swarthmore"/>
Her concern for women and children led Gibbons to found the New York Diet Kitchen (to serve infants, the elderly and the poor). She had also served as president of the New York Committee for the Prevention and Regulation of Vice, directed to control prostitution, drinking and gambling.{{Citation needed|date=May 2011}}
==Death== Gibbons died of pneumonia in New York in 1893, aged 91. She was eulogized in her obituary as "one of the most remarkable women of the century" for her work in noted reform movements. <ref> http://asp6new.alexanderstreet.com/was2/was2.object.details.aspx?dorpid=1000640987</ref> She is interred at [[Green-Wood Cemetery]] in [[Brooklyn]], [[New York (state)|New York]].
==Legacy== *Her daughter Sarah Emerson Gibbons edited and wrote a biography of Abigail Hopper Gibbons, published in 1896, which was based in part on her letters. *The WPA has continued, providing programs through which women can acquire the life skills needed to gain and keep employment, manage finances, and to make good choices for themselves and their families. It is the nation's oldest advocacy organization working exclusively with women prisoners.
==References== {{reflist}}
== Further reading == *Becker, Dorothy G.: ''Abigail Hopper Gibbons'' (New York, 1989) *Gibbons, Sarah Emerson: ''The Life of Abby Hopper Gibbons as Told Chiefly Through Her Correspondence'' (1896) <ref>https://books.google.com/books?id=vQUZAAAAYAAJ&printsec=frontcover&source=gbs_ge_summary_r&cad=0#v=onepage&q&f=false</ref> *Martin, Edward Sandford: ''The Life of Joseph Hodges Choate: As Gathered Chiefly from his Letters'' (New York, 1920), 2 volumes *Gray, Christopher: "Streetscapes/Readers' Questions; Lamartine Place, and Women Running Elevators", ''New York Times'', 7 June 1998 *Sacks, Marcy S.: ''Before Harlem: The Black Experience in New York City Before World War I,'' (University Pennsylvania Press, 2006)
==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20050421194549/http://www.alexanderstreet2.com/CWLDLive/BIOS/A3BIO.html Civil War biography], Alexander Street *[http://www.wpaonline.org Women's Prison Association official website] *[http://video.nationalgeographic.com/video/national-geographic-channel/specials-1/history-events/ngc-an-unsung-war-hero/ "An Unsung War Hero"], Clip from ''National Geographic'' film, ''Civil Warriors: Free at Last'' *[http://www.green-wood.com/burial_results/index.php] Green-Wood Cemetery Burial Search *[https://books.google.com/books?id=vQUZAAAAYAAJ&printsec=frontcover&source=gbs_ge_summary_r&cad=0#v=onepage&q&f=false], ''The Life of Abby Hopper Gibbons Told Chiefly Through Her Correspondence'', edited by Sarah Emerson Gibbons {{Authority control}}

| nationality = [[Nigeria]] }} '''Adepeju Opeyemi Jaiyeoba''' (born November 1983) is a [[Nigeria]]n social entrepreneur and activist who created the [[Brown Button Foundation]] as well as Mother's Delivery Kit which creates low cost health care options and delivery kits containing basic sterile supplies for expectant mothers in [[Nigeria]]. ==Life== Jaiyeoba trained as a [[lawyer]] and attended [[Obafemi Awolowo University]] Ile-Ife. She also has background training in Business and Entrepreneurship from the [[University of Texas]] at Austin USA as well as the Coady International Institute, Canada. Jaiyeoba's mission to reduce maternal and child mortality was as a result of the death of a close friend during childbirth in 2011 and reports of another. She found out that 145 women die in childbirth and 2,300 children die before reaching the age of five in Nigeria.{{Cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/women-in-leadership/2015/mar/27/ten-mins-with-adepeju-jaiyeoba-maternity-campaigner|title=10 minutes with: Adepeju Jaiyeoba, maternity campaigner|last=Minter|first=Harriet|date=2015-03-27|website=the Guardian|language=en|access-date=2018-05-09}} [[File:Mothers Deliver.jpg|thumb|Brown Button Foundation kit]] Jaiyeoba was mentioned by [[Barack Obama]] in his address in 2014 to the Young African Leaders Presidential Summit in [[Washington, D.C.|Washington]] and was also hosted at the [[White House]] in 2015. In 2014 they started delivering birth kits having seen the damage that lack of sterile supplies such as rusty blades used for severing umbilical cords during childbirth can have. By 2015 they had distributed 8,000 kits and by 2017, 300,000. In 2017 she gave a [[TEDx talk]].{{Citation|last=TEDx Talks|title=How to reform the health care system {{!}} Adepeju Jaiyeoba {{!}} TEDxGbagada|date=2017-06-30|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=JF_o2gtrlZY|accessdate=2018-05-09}} She has spoken at a number of local and international events and continues to inspire young people across Africa to action. ==Awards== *She is a White House Emerging Global Entrepreneur *She is a PATH International Innovation Champion *2018 USADF and Citi Foundation Venture showcase winner *Frost and Sullivan African Sterilized birth kit innovation award winner * One of 2017 100 most inspiring women in Nigeria *2017 Crans Montana Young Leader of Tomorrow awardee *JCI top 10 Outstanding Young Persons of the World awardee 2017 *JCI top 10 Outstanding Young Person of Nigeria awardee 2017 *D-Prize awardee in Global Health *2014 Mandela Washington Fellow *Fellow of the Unreasonable Institute *Women in Successful Careers (WISCAR) member *2015 Young Innovator of the World Innovation Summit for Health (WISH){{Cite web|url=https://jci.cc/zh/news/31748|title=JCI|website=jci.cc|access-date=2018-05-09}} *Africa's top 10 female entrepreneur for Diaspora Demo day *2015 YNaija top 10 most influential Nigerians under 40 (Advocacy) *2015 Cordes Fellow. == Links == {{Empty section|date=October 2018}} ==References== {{reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Jaiyeoba, Adepeju}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Nigerian people]] [[Category:1983 births]]

{{Infobox officeholder | name = Armando Hart | image = Armando Hart.jpg | caption = Armando Hart in [[Berlin]] in 1963. | birth_date = {{birth date|1930|06|13|df=yes}} | birth_place = [[Havana]], [[Cuba]] | death_date = {{death date and age|2017|11|26|1930|06|13|df=yes}} | death_place = Havana, Cuba | spouse = [[Haydée Santamaría]] | relations = [[Abel Santamaría]] (brother-in-law) | children = [[Celia Hart]] (1963–2008)
Abel Santamaría Hart (1960–2008) | awards = }} '''Armando Hart Dávalos''' (June 13, 1930 – November 26, 2017)[https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/the_americas/armando-hart-historic-cuban-revolutionary-figure-dies/2017/11/26/07df965c-d305-11e7-9ad9-ca0619edfa05_story.html "Armando Hart, historic Cuban Revolutionary figure, dies"] (''[[The Washington Post]]'') was a [[Cuba]]n [[politician]] and a [[Communist]] leader. His grandfather was born in [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]], [[United States|USA]] and emigrated to Cuba as a child. ==Biography== Before the [[Cuban Revolution]] which ousted President [[Fulgencio Batista]], Hart studied to be a lawyer at the [[University of Havana]]. While there, he became politically active and would soon join [[Fidel Castro]] and [[Che Guevara]] in their fight against Batista. As Castro and Che Guevara were leading the [[guerrilla warfare]] in the Cuban mountains and [[Cuban moist forests|jungles]], Hart went onto become one of the main organizers of the revolutionary movement in the cities. When Batista was finally overthrown, Hart was made the first Minister of Education of the Revolution, and later served as the Minister of Culture (1976-1997), as well as a member of the [[Politburo]] of the [[Communist Party of Cuba]]. In January 2005, Hart wrote an article on [[Joseph Stalin]], in which he denounced the ideas of [[Stalinism]] and its practice, while defending the ideas of [[Karl Marx]], [[Vladimir Lenin]], Fidel Castro, and [[Leon Trotsky]].[http://www.socialistviewpoint.org/mayjun_05/mayjun_05_08.htm Infto at socialistviewpoint.org] Armando Hart was the father of [[Celia Hart]]. He became minister of culture since the creation of that ministry on 1976 to 1997. He was then appointed director of the Office of José Martí′s Program. Hart was the president of the [[José Martí Cultural Society]] (Sociedad Cultural José Martí){{es icon}} [http://www.martiano.cult.cu José Martí Cultural Society website] at the time of this death. ==Orders and honors== *[[Order of José Martí]] (June 13, 2010)[http://www.juventudrebelde.co.cu/cuba/2010-06-12/raul-castro-awards-armando-hart-davalos-jose-marti-order "Raúl Castro awards Armando Hart Dávalos with José Martí Order"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110718163855/http://www.juventudrebelde.co.cu/cuba/2010-06-12/raul-castro-awards-armando-hart-davalos-jose-marti-order |date=2011-07-18 }} (''[[Juventud Rebelde]]'') ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{Commons category|Armando Hart}} * [https://web.archive.org/web/20110929115045/http://www.cadenagramonte.cubaweb.cu/english/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=2344%3A-armando-hart-receives-award-from-cuban-journalists&catid=2%3Acuba&Itemid=14 Armando Hart Receives Award from Cuban Journalists] * [https://groups.yahoo.com/group/CubaNews/message/116104 ACN: Dominican University Grants Honoris Causa Degree to Cuban Scholar] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20060902064445/http://ctp.iccas.miami.edu/Organizational/Biographies/Armando%20Hart%20Davalos.pdf Armando Hart Dávalos on ctp.iccas.miami.edu] {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Hart, Armando}} [[Category:1930 births]] [[Category:2017 deaths]] [[Category:Communist Party of Cuba politicians]] [[Category:Government ministers of Cuba]] [[Category:People of the Cuban Revolution]] [[Category:People from Havana]] [[Category:Cuban people of American descent]] {{Cuba-politician-stub}}

{{refimprove|date=September 2012}} '''Arthur Garner''' (born 8 February 1851) was a theatrical entrepreneur, active in Australia.<ref name=Mennell>{{cite Australasia|Garner, Arthur}}</ref>
==Background== [[File:Princess Theatre, Melbourne, Australia.jpg|thumb|The Princess's Theatre, Melbourne. Built in 1886 by Garner, Williamson & Musgrove]] Garner was born in [[Bath, Somerset]], England, where his father, Dr. Jonathan Garner (M.D. of Edinburgh) practised his profession, his mother being a Miss Cobden. Arthur Garner was articled to [[Charles J. Phipps]], the architect, whose connection was largely theatrical, he having erected no less than forty English theatres; from which circumstance may perhaps be traced the young pupil's gravitation to the stage, where he became a ''protégé'' of Mr. George Gordon, the scenic artist. From the paint-room Garner soon found his way to the footlights, and for some time appeared in various provincial companies.<ref name=Mennell/>
==Early years== In 1873 Garner arrived in [[Melbourne]], returning to London in 1876. In 1879 Garner began his career as an Australian entrepreneur by taking out "The London Comedy Company" (1879), of which Fred Marshall was the bright particular comic star and Mr. George Gordon the hardly less indispensable scenic artist.<ref name=Mennell/> Garner opened Garner's Theatre (previously [[White's Rooms]]) in [[Adelaide]] in 1880.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ausstage.edu.au/pages/contributor/?id=407326 |title=Arthur Garner |publisher=AusStage |accessdate=24 September 2012}}</ref> In 1881 Garner joined [[J. C. Williamson]], the eminent Australian-American actor, and [[George Musgrove]] in establishing the leading firm of Australasian managers, generally known as the "Trio," which has controlled a greater number of theatres and entered into engagements, dramatic and operatic, on a larger scale than has ever been attempted in the southern hemisphere.<ref name=Mennell/> Their operations practically commenced at the [[Theatre Royal, Melbourne]], on July 1, 1882, with the production of [[Gilbert and Sullivan]]'s [[Patience (opera)|''Patience'']]. Many eminent London ''artistes'' were introduced to the colonies under their regime; but the most substantial undertaking of Williamson, Garner & Musgrove was the building of the new [[Princess Theatre, Melbourne|Princess's Theatre, Melbourne]], in 1886, regarded as one of the finest theatres in the world.
==Married Life== Garner was twice married: first, to the noted English actress Blanche Stammers, who died in Melbourne in 1883; and, secondly, to Letitia Hill Martin, sister of [[Patchett Martin]], herself an accomplished ''littérateur'', and formerly a contributor to the Australian press.<ref name=Mennell/>
They retired to England, living at 36 Kempshott-road, [[Streatham Common]], Surrey. He died sometime before 1911.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article120696931 |title=Frederick de Belleville |newspaper=[[Sunday Times]] |issue=1335 |location=New South Wales, Australia |date=20 August 1911 |accessdate=3 April 2016 |page=20 |via=National Library of Australia}}</ref>
==External links== *[http://acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/item/itemLarge.aspx?itemID=448974 Photograph of Garner] at State Library, N.S.W.
==References== {{Reflist}}

{{URL|benmurraybruce.com}} }} '''Benedict Murray-Bruce''', [[Order of the Niger|OON]] (born 18 February 1956) is a Nigerian [[business magnate]] and [[politician]]. He is the founder of [[Silverbird Group]].{{cite web |url=http://silverbirdtv.com/personality-week/8103-personality-week-ben-murray-bruce |title=Personality of The Week: Ben Murray Bruce |work=Silverbird TV |date=18 February 2015 |accessdate=11 May 2015}} A member of the [[People's Democratic Party (Nigeria)|People's Democratic Party]], he was elected to the [[Senate of Nigeria]] in March 2015 where he currently represents the Bayelsa East constituency, in [[Bayelsa State]], Nigeria. ==Early life and education== Ben Murray-Bruce was born in Lagos, to [[Ijaw people|Ijaw]] parents Mullighan and Margaret Murray-Bruce who both hail from [[Akassa]], [[Bayelsa State]], Nigeria. He attended Our Lady of Apostles, [[Yaba, Lagos|Yaba]], Lagos, where he completed his primary education and St Gregory College, Obalende where he obtained the West African School Certificate before he proceeded to the [[University of South Carolina]] in the [[United States]], where he received a Bachelor's degree in [[Marketing]] in 1979.{{cite web | url=http://www.biographyhome.com/2013/03/ben-murray-bruce.html | title=Ben Murray Bruce | work=Biography Home | date=13 March 2013 | accessdate=2015-06-17 | author=Richard Osunde}} ==Career== ===Early beginnings=== Ben has served in various public positions. He served as Director General of [[Nigerian Television Authority]] from 1999 to 2003. Prior to starting Silverbird Group, he promoted the [[Miss Universe]] Nigeria Pageant in 1983, Miss Intercontinental Pageant, 1986-1994 and to date, he promotes the annual [[Most Beautiful Girl in Nigeria|Most Beautiful Girl in Nigeria Pageant]] which he began in 1986. He is currently a Member of the Board of National Arts Theatre, Nigerian Film Corporation, Federal Films Censors Board, National Film Distribution Company and Nigerian Anti- Piracy Action Committee.{{cite web |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/research/stocks/people/person.asp?personId=51602936&ticker=NSLTECH:NL | title=Ben Murray-Bruce | accessdate=2015-06-17}} ===Show business=== In an interview with ''Connect Nigeria'', Ben said he got into show business "by accident".{{cite web | url=http://www.vanguardngr.com/2014/12/peep-ben-bruce-business-empire/ | title=A peep into Ben Bruce business empire | publisher=Vanguard Nigeria | date=27 December 2014 | accessdate=2015-06-17 | author=Florence Amagiya}} His passion for show business made him and his wife to establish the now defunct ''Silverbird Magazine'' in 1980 with a loan from his father. Ben later went into promoting concerts.{{cite web | url=http://www.mtvmeets.com/%28S%28fdb5ofvrj3fwe0lgdxrzwhce%29%29/index.do?ix=22413&AspxAutoDetectCookieSupport=1 | title=Ben Murray Bruce | publisher=MTVBase Meets | accessdate=2015-06-17}} ===Politics=== In 2011, Ben Murray-Bruce ran for the governorship of Bayelsa State which was unsuccessful after he was screened out of the gubernatorial race under the umbrella of the [[People's Democratic Party (Nigeria)|People's Democratic Party]].{{cite web | url=http://www.vanguardngr.com/2011/11/bayelsa-guber-ticket-pdp-finally-drops-sylva-alaibe-bruce/ | title=Bayelsa Guber ticket: PDP finally drops Sylva, Alaibe, Bruce | publisher=Vanguard Nigeria | date=14 November 2011 | accessdate=2015-06-17 | authors=Emmanuel Aziken, Political Editor, Samuel Oyadongha & Henry Umoru}} On 27 October 2014, Ben later declared his intention to represent Bayelsa East Senatorial District at the National Assembly under the umbrella of the People's Democratic Party which he went on to win.{{cite web | url=http://dailypost.ng/2014/10/28/ben-murray-bruce-joins-race-senate/ | title=Ben Murray-Bruce joins race for Senate | publisher=DailyPost Nigeria | date=28 October 2014 | accessdate=2015-06-17 | author=Timothy Enietan-Matthews}}{{cite web | url=http://www.cknnigeria.com/2015/03/ben-bruce-wins-election-into-senate.html | title=Ben Bruce Wins Election Into The Senate | publisher=CKN Nigeria | date=30 March 2015 | accessdate=2015-06-17 | author=CKN Nigeria}} ==Awards and recognition== *"Showbiz Icon of the Year Award" (2005) *"“Top Ten” Significant Nigerian Businessmen Award" (2006) *"Life Achiever Award" (2006) *"Champion for Nation Building Award" (2007) *"Excellent Personality Award" (2009) *"Officer of [[Order of the Niger|the Order of the Niger]]" (2014){{cite web | url=http://www.premiumtimesng.com/news/top-news/168797-jonathan-names-nigerias-national-flag-designer-akinkunmi-special-aide-for-life.html | title=Jonathan names Nigeria’s national flag designer, Akinkunmi, special aide for life | publisher=Premium Times | date=29 September 2014 | accessdate=2015-06-18 | author=Richard Akinwumi}} ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== * {{good article}} {{Infobox person |name = Bobbi Campbell |image = File:Newsweek cover, August 8, 1983, showing Bobbi Campbell and Bobby Hilliard.jpg |caption = Bobbi Campbell (left), with his lover Bobby Hilliard, on the cover of ''[[Newsweek]]'', August 8, 1983 |birth_date = {{Birth date|1952|1|28}} |birth_place = [[Columbus, Georgia]] |birth_name = Robert Boyle Campbell, Jr. |death_date = {{Death date and age|1984|8|15|1952|1|28}} |death_place = [[San Francisco]], [[California]] |death_cause = [[Cryptosporidiosis]], resulting from [[HIV/AIDS|AIDS]] |resting_place = New Tacoma Cemetery, [[Tacoma, Washington]] | |other_names = {{Plainlist}} * "[[Kaposi's sarcoma|KS]] poster boy" * "AIDS poster boy" {{Endplainlist}} |known_for = [[HIV/AIDS|AIDS]] activism, co-writing the [[Denver Principles]] |occupation = Public health nurse |nationality = American }} '''Robert Boyle "Bobbi" Campbell Jr.''' (January 28, 1952 – August 15, 1984)<ref name="Family Search">{{cite web |url=https://familysearch.org/ark:/61903/1:1:VG18-5C7 |title=Robert Boyle Campbell |work=California Death Index, 1940–1997 |date=November 26, 2014 |accessdate=November 17, 2016 |via=[[FamilySearch]] }}</ref> was a public health nurse and an early [[United States]] [[HIV/AIDS|AIDS]] [[activism|activist]]. In September 1981, Campbell became the 16th person in [[San Francisco]] to be diagnosed with [[Kaposi's sarcoma]],<ref name="Inglis">{{cite web |url=https://sensualpoet.blogspot.co.uk/2004_02_22_archive.html |title=The Exhumation of Bobbi Campbell (28 Jan 1952 – 15 Aug 1984) |author=Alexander Inglis |publisher=[[Blogger (service)|Blogger]] |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161114153309/https://sensualpoet.blogspot.co.uk/2004_02_22_archive.html |deadurl=no |date=February 25, 2004 |archivedate=November 14, 2016 |accessdate=November 13, 2016 }}</ref> when that was a proxy for an AIDS diagnosis.<ref name="Rare cancer NYT">{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1981/07/03/us/rare-cancer-seen-in-41-homosexuals.html |title=Rare cancer seen in 41 homosexuals |date=July 3, 1981 |author=Lawrence K. Altman |work=[[The New York Times]] |accessdate=July 19, 2015 }}</ref> He was the first to [[coming out|come out]] publicly as a person with what came to be known as AIDS,<ref name="Callen & Turner">{{cite book |chapter-url=http://michaelcallen.com/mikes-writing/a-history-of-the-pwa-self-empowerment-movement/ |chapter=A History of the PWA Self-Empowerment Movement |author1=[[Michael Callen]] |author2=[[Dan Turner (AIDS activist)|Dan Turner]] |lastauthoramp=yes |title=Surviving and Thriving With AIDS: Collected Wisdom, Volume 2 |editor=Michael Callen |location=[[New York City]] |publisher=People With AIDS Coalition |year=1988 |pages=288–293 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150109085634/http://michaelcallen.com/mikes-writing/a-history-of-the-pwa-self-empowerment-movement/ |deadurl=no |archivedate=January 9, 2015 |accessdate=November 16, 2016 }}<!-- See http://www.medscape.com/viewarticle/811663_1 footnote 11 for the book reference details --></ref><ref name="Berkowitz">{{cite news |url=http://www.poz.com/archive/february1997/upfront/retropoz.html |title=The Way We War |first=Richard |last=Berkowitz |authorlink=Richard Berkowitz |work=[[POZ (magazine)|POZ]] |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20020616020814/http://www.poz.com/archive/february1997/upfront/retropoz.html |date=February 1997 |archivedate=June 16, 2002 |accessdate=November 28, 2016 }}</ref> writing a regular column in the ''[[San Francisco Sentinel]]'', syndicated nationwide, describing his experiences<ref name="BAR obit 1984-08-16">{{cite news |url=http://obit.glbthistory.org/olo/imagedb/1984/08/16/19840816_Campbell_Bobbi/m19840816_0.jpg |title=Bobbi Campbell's Long Fight Ends |author=Brian Jones |work=[[Bay Area Reporter]] |date=August 16, 1984 |accessdate=November 14, 2016 }} Via the [http://obit.glbthistory.org/olo/display.jsp?name=19840816_Campbell_Bobbi Online Searchable Obituary Database] of the [[GLBT Historical Society]]</ref> and posting photos of his KS lesions to help other San Franciscans know what to look for,<ref name="How to Survive a Plague p107–8">{{cite book |url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=I31ODAAAQBAJ&lpg=PA103&pg=PA107 |title=How to Survive a Plague: The Story of How Activists and Scientists Tamed AIDS |author=[[David France (writer)|David France]] |publisher=Pan Macmillan |date=December 1, 2016 |accessdate=September 21, 2017 |pages=107–108 |isbn=978-1-5098-3941-4 }}</ref><ref name="Schietinger p105">Interview with [[Helen Schietinger]], nurse coordinator of UCSF's first AIDS clinic, on January 30, 1995, by Sally Smith Hughes — in {{cite book |url=https://archive.org/stream/aidsepidemicsf01bancrich/#page/104 |title=The AIDS Epidemic in San Francisco: The Response of the Nursing Profession, 1981–1984, volume I |series=The San Francisco AIDS Oral History Series |publisher=Regional Oral History Office, The Bancroft Library, [[University of California, Berkeley]] |year=1999 |page=105 }}</ref><ref name="Star Pharmacy Plaque">{{cite web |url=http://letskickass.org/walgreens-hivaids-castro-sprit-historical-plaque/ |title=Walgreens HIV/AIDS Castro Spirit Historical Plaque |author=Tez Anderson |publisher=Let's Kick ASS—AIDS Survivor Syndrome |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150618040532/http://letskickass.org/walgreens-hivaids-castro-sprit-historical-plaque/ |date=June 17, 2015<!-- see source timestamp 2015-06-17T15:20:59+00:00 --> |archivedate=June 18, 2015 |accessdate=November 15, 2016 }}</ref> as well as helping write the first San Francisco [[safer sex]] manual.<ref name="Schietinger p147">Interview with [[Helen Schietinger]], nurse coordinator of UCSF's first AIDS clinic, on January 30, 1995, by Sally Smith Hughes — in {{cite book |url=https://archive.org/stream/aidsepidemicsf01bancrich/#page/146 |title=The AIDS Epidemic in San Francisco: The Response of the Nursing Profession, 1981–1984, volume I |series=The San Francisco AIDS Oral History Series |publisher=Regional Oral History Office, The Bancroft Library, [[University of California, Berkeley]] |year=1999 |page=147 }}</ref>
He rapidly became one of the leading activists co-founding [[People With AIDS]] San Francisco in 1982<ref name="Callen & Turner"/><ref name="Berkowitz"/><ref name="Smith & Siplon">{{cite book |title=Drugs Into Bodies: Global AIDS Treatment Activism |url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=_bmWVajp-ooC&pg=PA16 |author1=Raymond A. Smith |author2=Patricia D. Siplon |pages=16–18 |year=2006 |publisher=Greenwood Publishing Group |isbn=978-0-275-98325-3 |accessdate=November 12, 2016 }}</ref> and then, the following year, with HIV+ men from across the U.S., he co-wrote the [[Denver Principles]],<ref name="Callen & Turner"/><ref name="Smith & Siplon"/> the defining manifesto of the People With AIDS Self-Empowerment Movement.<ref name="Callen & Turner"/><ref name="Smith & Siplon"/> Appearing on the cover of ''[[Newsweek]]'' and being interviewed on national news reports,<ref name="Inglis"/><ref name="Shilts PT575">{{cite book |author=[[Randy Shilts]] |title=And the Band Played On: Politics, People and the AIDS Epidemic |url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=nYs8AAAAQBAJ&pg=PT575 |publisher=Souvenir Press |page=575 |date=November 3, 2011 |isbn=978-0-285-64076-4 }}</ref><ref name="BAR obit 1984-08-23">{{cite news |url=http://obit.glbthistory.org/olo/imagedb/1984/08/16/19840816_Campbell_Bobbi/m19840823_0.jpg |title=Candles and Tears on Castro: 1,000 Mourn Bobbi Campbell |author=Allen White |work=[[Bay Area Reporter]] |date=August 23, 1984 |accessdate=November 14, 2016 }} Via the [http://obit.glbthistory.org/olo/display.jsp?name=19840816_Campbell_Bobbi Online Searchable Obituary Database] of the [[GLBT Historical Society]]</ref> Campbell raised the national profile of the AIDS crisis among heterosexuals and provided a recognizable face of the epidemic for affected communities.<ref name="Inglis"/> He also lobbied [[Margaret Heckler]], [[United States Secretary of Health and Human Services|Secretary of Health and Human Services]] in the [[Presidency of Ronald Reagan|Reagan administration]] over both practical issues and stigmatising medical practices affecting people with AIDS.<ref name="How to Survive a Plague p115–6">{{cite book |url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=I31ODAAAQBAJ&lpg=PA116&pg=PA116 |title=How to Survive a Plague: The Story of How Activists and Scientists Tamed AIDS |author=[[David France (writer)|David France]] |publisher=Pan Macmillan |date=December 1, 2016 |accessdate=September 21, 2017 |pages=115–116 |isbn=978-1-5098-3941-4 }}</ref> He also continued to campaign for LGBT+ rights, speaking outside the [[1984 Democratic National Convention]]<ref name="DNC YouTube">{{cite AV media |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=y9uceO78lHs |title=Bobbi Campbell speech (1984) |publisher=[[GLBT Historical Society]] |date=July 15, 1984 |access-date=July 19, 2015 |via=[[YouTube]] }}</ref> a month before his death from [[cryptosporidiosis]].<ref name="How to Survive a Plague p153–4">{{cite book |url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=I31ODAAAQBAJ&lpg=PA103&pg=PA153 |title=How to Survive a Plague: The Story of How Activists and Scientists Tamed AIDS |author=[[David France (writer)|David France]] |publisher=Pan Macmillan |date=December 1, 2016 |accessdate=September 21, 2017 |pages=153–154 |isbn=978-1-5098-3941-4 }}</ref>
== Before the AIDS crisis == Born in [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]] in 1952<ref name="Family Search"/> and raised in [[Tacoma, Washington]],<ref name="Shilts PT138–39">{{cite book |author=[[Randy Shilts]] |title=And the Band Played On: Politics, People and the AIDS Epidemic |url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=nYs8AAAAQBAJ&pg=PT138 |publisher=Souvenir Press |pages=138–39 |date=November 3, 2011 |isbn=978-0-285-64076-4 }}</ref> Bobbi Campbell earned a degree in nursing from the [[University of Washington]]<ref name="Atkins p299">{{cite book |url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=xhoKGmBbm-AC&dq=%22Bobbi+Campbell%22&pg=PA299 |title=Gay Seattle: Stories of Exile and Belonging |author=Gary Atkins |publisher=University of Washington Press |year=2003 |page=299 |isbn=978-0-295-98298-4 }}</ref> and volunteered at The Seattle Counseling Services for Sexual Minorities,<ref name="Atkins p299"/><ref name="OutHistory: 1960s Seattle">{{cite web |url=http://outhistory.org/exhibits/show/queen-city-comes-out/pioneer-square/1960s |title=1960s |author=The Northwest Lesbian & Gay History Museum Project |work=Queen City Comes Out: Exploring Seattle's Lesbian and Gay History |publisher=Out History |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150329234346/http://outhistory.org/exhibits/show/queen-city-comes-out/pioneer-square/1960s |archivedate= March 29, 2015 |accessdate=October 7, 2017 }}</ref> the first gay-run counseling service for gay people in the country,<ref name="OutHistory: 1960s Seattle"/> while being politically active in [[Seattle]] during the city's initial wave of gay liberation in the 1970s.<ref name="Atkins p299"/><ref name="Atkins p374">{{cite book |url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=xhoKGmBbm-AC&dq=%22Bobbi+Campbell%22&pg=PA374 |title=Gay Seattle: Stories of Exile and Belonging |author=Gary Atkins |publisher=University of Washington Press |year=2003 |page=374 |isbn=978-0-295-98298-4 }}</ref> He lived communally in [[Capitol Hill (Seattle)|Capitol Hill]] with other gay male activists at what was known informally as the "East John Street Gay Men's Collective", described by his former lover Tom Richards as "a notorious and famous house with colorful and smart people."<ref>Mentioned in an interview with Tom Richards by Charlie Fuchs and Larry Knopp of the Northwest Lesbian and Gay History Museum Project in July 2000, cited in a footnote from page 299 of Atkins's book ''Gay Seattle: Stories of Exile and Belonging''.</ref>
Campbell moved from Seattle to San Francisco in 1975,<ref name="Wright 2013">{{cite journal |url=http://www.medscape.com/viewarticle/811663 |title=Only Your Calamity: The Beginnings of Activism by and for People With AIDS |author=Joe Wright |journal=[[American Journal of Public Health]] |year=2013 |volume=103 |issue=10 |pages=1788–98 |doi=10.2105/AJPH.2013.301381 |doi-access=free |url-access=registration |pmc=3780739 |pmid=23948013}}</ref> getting a job in a hospital near [[The Castro]] and immersing himself in the political and social life of the community,<ref name="Wright 2013"/> which had become a center for the [[LGBT community]] over the previous few years. By 1981, he had enrolled in a training program at [[University of California, San Francisco]], to become an adult health [[nurse practitioner]],<ref name="Wright 2013"/> with a view to focusing on healthcare in the gay and lesbian community.<ref name="Sentinel column #1">{{cite news |author=Bobbi Campbell |title=I Will Survive! Nurse's Own 'Gay Cancer' Story |work=[[San Francisco Sentinel]] |date=December 10, 1981 }} Cited in Wright (2013), ''[[American Journal of Public Health|Am J Pub Health]]''.<!-- per [[WP:SAYWHERE]] --></ref>
== Diagnosis and local activism == Starting with a case of [[shingles]] in February 1981,<ref name="Pacifica Radio">{{cite AV media |url=https://dl.dropboxusercontent.com/u/12012414/001survive.mp3 |title=I Will Survive |author=David Hunt |at=from 40:20 |type=Radio broadcast |location=[[Los Angeles]] |publisher=[[KPFK|Pacifica Radio KPFK 90.7 FM]] |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161116214140/https://dl.dropboxusercontent.com/u/12012414/001survive.mp3 |deadurl=yes |date=June 19, 1983 |archivedate=November 16, 2016 |accessdate=November 16, 2016 |format=MP3 |postscript=. }} Audio embedded in: {{cite web |url=http://www.gayinthe80s.com/2014/08/1983-hivaids-pacifica-radio-programme-i-will-survive/ |title=1983. HIV/AIDS: Pacifica Radio Programme, 'I Will Survive' |author=Colin Clews |work=Gay in the 80s |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150919153941/http://www.gayinthe80s.com/2014/08/1983-hivaids-pacifica-radio-programme-i-will-survive/ |deadurl=no |date=August 4, 2014 |archivedate=September 19, 2015 |accessdate=November 16, 2016 }}<!-- The audio can also be found in the producer (David Hunt)'s blogpost, at http://www.tellmedavid.com/2015/05/i-will-survive/, which is archived at https://web.archive.org/web/20161116214150/http://www.tellmedavid.com/2015/05/i-will-survive/ --></ref> Bobbi Campbell suffered a succession of unusual illnesses, including [[leukopenia]] later that summer.<ref name="Pacifica Radio"/> After hiking the [[Pinnacles National Park|Pinnacles National Monument]] with his boyfriend in September that year, he noticed on his feet lesions of [[Kaposi's sarcoma]] (KS),<ref name="Shilts PT138–39"/><ref name="Pacifica Radio"/> then thought of as a rare cancer of elderly Jewish men but with alarming numbers of cases appearing in California and [[New York City|New York]]<ref name="Rare cancer NYT"/><ref name="MMWR">{{cite journal |title=Kaposi's sarcoma and ''Pneumocycstis'' pneumonia among homosexual men – New York City and California |journal=[[Morbidity and Mortality Weekly Report]] |date=July 4, 1981 |volume=30 |issue=25 |pages=305–308 |url=https://stacks.cdc.gov/view/cdc/1265 |pmid=6789108 |publisher=[[Centers for Disease Control and Prevention|Centers for Disease Control]] |deadurl=no |accessdate=October 23, 2013 }}{{open access}}</ref> and now known to be closely associated with AIDS. He was formally diagnosed as having KS by dermatologist [[Marcus Conant]] on October 8, 1981.<ref name="Wright 2013"/><ref name="Pacifica Radio"/> This would become Conant's first diagnosis of a patient with what would become known as AIDS;<ref name="BAR obit 1984-08-23"/> Campbell brought Conant a rose every year to commemorate the anniversary of his diagnosis.<ref name="BAR obit 1984-08-23"/>
While the ''[[New York Native]]'' was printing several stories about the "gay cancer" beginning to make its way round the city, with detailed medical writing by [[Lawrence D. Mass]], a gay physician and psychiatrist,<ref name="Shilts PT138–39"/> the San Francisco gay press largely ignored the nascent epidemic.<ref name="Shilts PT138–39"/> Campbell's interest in educational outreach and professional interest in gay sexual health combined to inspire him to raise awareness himself.<ref name="Shilts PT138–39"/> As a result, in October 1981, the same month he was diagnosed, Campbell put pictures of his KS lesions in the window of the Star Pharmacy at 498 Castro Street, urging men with similar lesions to seek medical attention.<ref name="How to Survive a Plague p107–8"/><ref name="Schietinger p105"/><ref name="Star Pharmacy Plaque"/> In doing so, he created and displayed San Francisco's first AIDS poster.<ref name="Andriote">{{cite book |url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=dAI7nOe1KfYC&pg=PA170 |title=Victory Deferred: How AIDS Changed Gay Life in America |author=John-Manuel Andriote |publisher=University of Chicago Press |pages=170–72 |date=June 1, 1999 |isbn=978-0-226-02049-5 }}</ref>
After speaking with Randy Alfred, a friend and editor of the ''[[San Francisco Sentinel]]'', Campbell agreed to write a column, "to demystify the AIDS story".<ref name="Pacifica Radio"/> In his first article, on December 10, 1981, he proclaimed himself to be the "KS Poster Boy"<ref name="Shilts PT138–39"/> (later "AIDS Poster Boy"),<ref name="Star Pharmacy Plaque"/><ref name="Shilts PT575"/><ref name="BAR obit 1984-08-23"/> becoming the first person in the US to publicly disclose that he was suffering from "gay cancer",<ref name="Callen & Turner"/><ref name="Berkowitz"/> writing:<ref name="Shilts PT138–39"/><ref name="Sentinel column #1"/> {{Quote |text=The purpose of the poster boy is to raise interest and money in a particular cause, and I do have aspirations of doing that regarding gay cancer. I'm writing because I have a determination to live. You do, too — Don't you? }}
This article turned into a regular column in the ''Sentinel'' — and syndicated in newspapers serving the LGBT community nationwide — describing his experiences.<ref name="BAR obit 1984-08-16"/> On January 10, 1982, Campbell was interviewed by Alfred for ''The Gay Life'' program on [[KSAN (FM)|KSAN-FM]], with doctors Marcus Conant and [[Paul Volberding]]; the interview has been archived by the [[GLBT Historical Society]].<ref name="Gayback search">The [[GLBT Historical Society]]'s "[http://www.glbthistory.org/archives/audio-search/ Gayback Machine]" search does not produce persistent URLs, but searching for "Bobbi Campbell" in 1981 will bring up the appropriate episode, dated 1982-01-10 and captioned "Marcus Conant, M.D. and Paul Volberding, M.D., U.C. San Francisco Medical School; Bobbi Campbell, Kaposi's Sarcoma cancer patient." It is also available offline as [http://www.oac.cdlib.org/findaid/ark:/13030/kt0w10244m/entire_text/#c02-1.3.11.3.124 Reel 118, Box 16] from ''Randy Alfred subject files and sound recordings'', collection 1991-24, GLBT Historical Society.</ref>
Campbell joined the [[Sisters of Perpetual Indulgence]]<ref name="Star Pharmacy Plaque"/><ref name="Schietinger p147"/> at the time of the health crisis in early 1982; in his "sister" persona as Sister Florence Nightmare RN,<ref name="Callen & Turner"/><ref name="Andriote"/> he co-authored the first San Francisco [[safe sex|safer sex]] manual, ''Play Fair!'', written in plain [[sex-positive movement|sex-positive]] language, using humor to leaven practical advice.<ref name="Schietinger p147"/> The Sisters were early awareness and fundraisers for the oncoming AIDS pandemic and continue to raise awareness of [[reproductive health|sexual health]]; many Orders regularly pass out [[condom]]s and participate in events to educate people on sexual health issues.<ref name="sistory">{{cite web |url=http://www.thesisters.org/content/sistory |title=Sistory |publisher=[[Sisters of Perpetual Indulgence]] |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110725230125/http://www.thesisters.org/content/sistory |deadurl=yes |date=2010 |archivedate=25 July 2011 |accessdate=17 September 2017 }}</ref>
In February 1982, on the invitation of Conant and Volberding,<ref name="Callen & Turner"/><ref name="Andriote"/> Campbell and [[Dan Turner (AIDS activist)|Dan Turner]], who had just himself been diagnosed with KS,<ref name="Andriote"/> attended what turned out to be the founding meeting of the KS/AIDS Foundation, which later became the [[San Francisco AIDS Foundation]],<ref name="Andriote"/> of which Campbell then served on the board.<ref name="Smith & Siplon"/> Campbell also became involved with the [[Shanti Project]] (which moved from its original focus, supporting people with terminal cancer, to help provide emotional support to people diagnosed with AIDS coming to terms with death)<ref name="Helquist">Interview with [[Michael Helquist]], journalist of the early AIDS epidemic in San Francisco, on March 24, 1995, by Sally Smith Hughes — in {{cite book |url=https://archive.org/stream/aidsepidemicsf01bancrich/#page/30 |title=The AIDS Epidemic in San Francisco: The Response of the Nursing Profession, 1981–1984, volume I |publisher=Regional Oral History Office, The Bancroft Library, [[University of California, Berkeley]] |year=1999 |page=30 }}</ref><ref name="Schietinger p153–5">Interview with [[Helen Schietinger]], nurse coordinator of UCSF's first AIDS clinic, on January 30, 1995, by Sally Smith Hughes — in {{cite book |url=https://archive.org/stream/aidsepidemicsf01bancrich/#page/152 |title=The AIDS Epidemic in San Francisco: The Response of the Nursing Profession, 1981–1984, volume I |series=The San Francisco AIDS Oral History Series |publisher=Regional Oral History Office, The Bancroft Library, [[University of California, Berkeley]] |year=1999 |pages=153–55 }}</ref> and persuaded reluctant physicians to allow him to meet and counsel AIDS patients at Conant's KS clinic.<ref name="Schietinger p153–5"/>
== The People With AIDS Movement == {{Main|People With AIDS}} In 1982, Campbell and Turner convened a meeting that spawned [[People With AIDS]] San Francisco,<ref name="Callen & Turner"/><ref name="Berkowitz"/><ref name="Smith & Siplon"/> founding the "People With AIDS Self-Empowerment Movement" or PWA Movement,<ref name="Callen & Turner"/><ref name="Berkowitz"/> rapidly followed by [[Michael Callen]] and [[Richard Berkowitz]], authors of ''[[How to Have Sex in an Epidemic]]'', in [[New York City]].<ref name="Smith & Siplon"/> As well as arguing that people with AIDS should expect to participate actively in the response to the AIDS crisis, the PWA Movement rejected the terms "AIDS victim" and "AIDS patient," as Campbell explained in interviews, for example:<ref name="Pacifica Radio"/>
{{Quote |text=The ''[[Bay Area Reporter|BAR]]'' ran a story on a friend of mine ... the headline read "Coalition treasurer KS victim" and my friend, who is the subject of this interview, was very unhappy because the implication of "KS victim" means the bus has run over you and you're laying there in the street, flattened. And he's very much alive; so am I. I do not feel like a "victim." }}
With other members of People With AIDS San Francisco, Campbell organized the first [[candlelight vigil|candlelight march]] to bring attention to the plight of people with AIDS and to remember those who had died of AIDS.<ref name="Berkowitz"/> On May 2, 1983, they marched behind a banner of "Fighting for our lives" for the first time,<ref name="Callen & Turner"/><ref name="Berkowitz"/> drawing around 10,000 people. On May 23, 1983, People With AIDS San Francisco voted to send Campbell and Turner to the Fifth National Lesbian and Gay Health Conference, at which the Second National AIDS Forum would be held.<ref name="Callen & Turner"/>
Campbell and his colleagues' push to persuade [[AIDS service organization|service organizations]] to sponsor gay men with AIDS to attend the Conference was a key moment in the People With AIDS Self-Empowerment Movement.<ref name="Callen & Turner"/><ref name="Andriote"/> Michael Callen subsequently wrote that, despite a growing sense of being patronised,<ref name="Smith & Siplon"/> it had not occurred to the AIDS-diagnosed New Yorkers to "be anything more than the passive recipients of the genuine care and concern";<ref name="Callen & Turner"/><ref name="Andriote"/> once people with AIDS realised they could advocate for themselves, lessons learned from the [[second-wave feminism|feminist]] and the [[civil rights movement]] helped with a more-widespread acceptance of the notion of self-empowerment.<ref name="Callen & Turner"/><ref name="Andriote"/>
The national PWA movement came fully together when Campbell took charge of a discussion<ref name="Callen & Turner"/><ref name="How to Survive a Plague p107–8"/><ref name="Andriote"/> where, with Callen, Turner and others,<ref name="Denver Principles attendees">Those in attendance included: * From San Francisco: Bobbi Campbell, [[Dan Turner (AIDS activist)|Dan Turner]] (1948–90), Bobby Reynolds (died 1987) and [[Michael Helquist]] representing his recently-deceased partner Mark Feldman * From New York City: Phil Lanzaratta (died 1986), [[Michael Callen]] (1955–93), [[Richard Berkowitz]], Artie Felson, Bill Burke, Bob Cecchi (1942–91), Matthew Sarner [[Master of Social Work|M.S.W.]], Tom Nasrallah * From Los Angeles: Gar Traynor Plus "someone named Elbert from Kansas City by way of Houston; and one individual from Denver whose name we unfortunately cannot recall". (See "Remembering Bobbi Campbell" from ''The Daily Seyahatname'' and "A History of the PWA Self-Empowerment Movement" by Callen and Turner.)</ref> he drafted the [[Denver Principles]], the defining manifesto of the PWA Movement,<ref name="Callen & Turner"/><ref name="Berkowitz"/><ref name="Star Pharmacy Plaque"/><ref name="Smith & Siplon"/><ref name="Andriote"/> which, again, start with the rejection of the terms "victim" and "patient."<ref name="Callen & Turner"/><ref name="Smith & Siplon"/><ref name="Andriote"/> Campbell and the San Franciscans had different thoughts on the origin ([[etiology]]) of AIDS from Callen and the New Yorkers — Campbell described as "crazy" the idea that AIDS was caused by promiscuity,<ref name="Pacifica Radio"/> a perspective espoused by Callen and Berkowitz (and their physician [[Joseph Sonnabend]]) at the time<ref name="We Know Who We Are">{{Cite news |url=https://richardberkowitz.com/tag/we-know-who-we-are/ |title=We Know Who We Are: Two Gay Men Declare War on Promiscuity |author1=[[Michael Callen]] |author2=[[Richard Berkowitz]] |author3=Richard Dworkin |work=[[New York Native]] |issue=Issue 50, November 8–21, 1982 |accessdate=November 17, 2016 }} Linked from {{cite web |url=https://richardberkowitz.com/2010/06/29/safe-sex-writing-1982-2008/ |title=My Safe Sex Writing 1982–2010 |author=[[Richard Berkowitz]] |date=June 29, 2010 |accessdate=November 17, 2016 }}</ref><ref name="Paternotte & Tremblay">{{cite book |url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=aPiqCwAAQBAJ&ots=k8lmYI2KgR&pg=PT91 |title=The Ashgate Research Companion to Lesbian and Gay Activism |author1=David Paternotte |author2=Manon Tremblay |publisher=Routledge |date=3 March 2016 |isbn=978-1-317-04290-7 }}</ref><ref name="amfAR: Joseph Sonnabend">{{cite web |title=2000 Honoring with Pride: Joseph Sonnabend, M.D |url=http://www.amfar.org/spotlight/article.aspx?id=4550 |publisher=[[amfAR, The Foundation for AIDS Research]] |date=2000 |accessdate=26 July 2014 }}</ref> — and the Denver Principles represent a "careful synthesis" of these two positions:<ref name="Wright 2013"/><ref>As Joe Wright explained in footnote 63 to his 2013 article in ''[[American Journal of Public Health]]'': "For example, the 'recommendations for all people' would have been easy points of agreement; the last of the 'recommendations for people with AIDS,' on [[sexual ethics]], underlines their agreements about [[safe sex]] but without delving into the language of 'promiscuity' or its rebuttals; and the second recommendation for health care providers appears to be a gentle assertion of [[Michael Callen|Callen]]'s concerns about [[etiology]], while the third likely reflects Campbell's own approach to how to be a clinician, and would have been the sort of instruction a progressive nursing educator might have given at the time."</ref>
The activists — in an echo of the [[Lavender Menace]] [[radical feminism|radical feminists]] storming the [[National Organization for Women|NOW]] convention stage in 1970<ref name="How to Survive a Plague PA109">{{cite book |url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=I31ODAAAQBAJ&lpg=PP1&dq=bobbi%20campbell&pg=PA109 |title=How to Survive a Plague: The Story of How Activists and Scientists Tamed AIDS |author=[[David France (writer)|David France]] |publisher=Pan Macmillan |date=December 1, 2016 |accessdate=September 17, 2017 |pages=109–10 |isbn=978-1-5098-3941-4 }}</ref> — decided to storm the stage of the closing session of the Second National AIDS Forum in order to present the Denver Principles. As each of the 11 men read out one of the 11 statements, they did so with the "Fighting for our lives" banner behind them, from the San Francisco march earlier that month; these words became the slogan of the PWA Movement.<ref name="Callen & Turner"/><ref name="How to Survive a Plague p107–8"/>
After the conference, Campbell flew to New York with Callen, Berkowitz and Artie Felson, organizing and planning for local and national PWA organizations on the plane.<ref name="Callen & Turner"/><ref name="Andriote"/> On arrival, they organized a PWA organization in the city despite initial opposition from the [[Gay Men's Health Crisis]].<ref name="Callen & Turner"/> They also planned a national PWA organization<ref name="Andriote"/> which opened in New York City in June 1984. PWA-New York went on to create the first safer sex poster to appear in a [[gay bathhouse]] in the city.<ref name="Callen & Turner"/>
In June 1984, the annual [[San Francisco Pride|San Francisco's Gay Freedom Day Parade]] was dedicated for the first time to people with AIDS. [[Dykes on Bikes]] have led the parade since the mid-1970s and People With AIDS followed immediately behind.<ref name="Callen & Turner"/>
== Wider activism == <!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:Bobbi Campbell at the Clinical Nursing Conference on AIDS at NIH, October 7, 1983.jpg|thumb|Bobbi Campbell presenting a [[poster session]] — to help clinicians and nurses understand the message of the Denver Principles — at the first Clinical Nursing Conference on AIDS at the [[National Institutes of Health]] on October 7, 1983]] --> Initially, there was very little coverage of the AIDS crisis outside the gay community — while 1982 saw 800 reported cases and 350 AIDS-related deaths in the USA,<ref name="Nelkin 1991">{{cite journal |author=Dorothy Nelkin |title=AIDS and the News Media |journal=[[The Milbank Quarterly]] |volume=69 |issue=2 |pages=293–307 |date=1991 |doi=10.2307/3350206 |jstor=3350206 and [[Wikipedia:The Wikipedia Library|The Wikipedia Library]] }}</ref> there were only 6 stories about AIDS on major [[news broadcasting#Network news programming|network news]]<ref name="Cook & Colby 1992">{{cite book |author1=Timothy Cook |author2=David Colby |date=1992 |chapter=The mass-mediated epidemic: The politics of AIDS on the nightly network news |url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=CmME6xfdEFAC&lpg=PR5&pg=PA89 |editor1=Elizabeth Fee |editor2=Daniel Fox |title=AIDS: The Making of a Chronic Disease |publisher=University of California Press |isbn=9-780-5200-7778-2 }}</ref> and [[print media]] up to May 1983 included little coverage beyond the gay press and the ''[[San Francisco Chronicle]]''<ref name="Nelkin 1991"/> — [[Lawrence Altman]], medical writer at ''[[The New York Times]]'' had a piece refused in 1981,<ref name="Nelkin 1991"/> and Jerry Bishop, a science writer at ''[[The Wall Street Journal]]'', had a piece on AIDS refused by his editor in early 1982,<ref name="Nelkin 1991"/> whereas the ''Chronicle'' hired [[Randy Shilts]] to report on AIDS full-time in 1982.<ref name="Nelkin 1991"/> Campbell and Conant featured in the earliest nationally-broadcast news reports on the "gay cancer" on June 12, 1982, where [[Barry Petersen]] interviewed Campbell, [[Larry Kramer]] and [[James W. Curran|James Curran]], who led the [[Centers for Disease Control and Prevention|CDC]] taskforce, for [[CBS News]].<ref name="CBS">{{cite AV media |author=[[Barry Petersen]] |title=Early CBS Report on AIDS |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=X23vKiBE88E |publisher=[[CBS News]] |via=[[YouTube]] |date=June 12, 1982 |accessdate=June 17, 2016 }}</ref>
After being criticised for omitting any coverage of a [[Madison Square Garden]] benefit in April 1983, ''The New York Times'' increased its coverage of AIDS, setting the tone for an increase across print media.<ref name="Nelkin 1991"/> One of the most high-profile early pieces introducing AIDS to the heterosexual community was the cover article of the August 8, 1983, edition of ''[[Newsweek]]'', showing Campbell and his lover Bobby Hilliard and headlined "EPIDEMIC: The Mysterious and Deadly Disease Called AIDS May Be the Public Health Threat of the Century. How Did it Start? Can it Be Stopped?"<ref name="Inglis"/><ref name="BAR obit 1984-08-23"/><ref name="ZeitGAYst">{{cite web |url=http://thestarryeye.typepad.com/gay/2012/08/the-issue-of-newsweek-that-hit-newsstands-on-august-2-1983-cover-date-of-august-8-was-notable-not-because-of-its-aids-cov.html |title=''Newsweek'' Puts a Human Face on AIDS (August 2, 1983) |author=Rob Frydlewicz |work=ZeitGAYst: A Look at History thru Pink-Colored Glasses |publisher=[[TypePad]] |date=August 2, 2012 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121019100021/http://thestarryeye.typepad.com/gay/2012/08/the-issue-of-newsweek-that-hit-newsstands-on-august-2-1983-cover-date-of-august-8-was-notable-not-because-of-its-aids-cov.html |deadurl=no |archivedate=October 19, 2012 |accessdate=November 16, 2016 }}</ref> — only the second time an [[coming out|openly gay]] man had appeared on the cover of a mass-market [[news magazine]],<ref name="Inglis"/><ref name="ZeitGAYst"/> albeit with Hilliard identified as Campbell's "friend."<ref name="UCSF A&SC">{{cite web |url=https://blogs.library.ucsf.edu/broughttolight/2013/07/17/preserving-history-of-hivaids-epidemic/ |title=Preserving History of HIV/AIDS Epidemic |author=Polina Ilieva |work=Brought to Light: Stories from UCSF Archives & Special Collections |publisher=[[University of California, San Francisco Archives and Special Collections|UCSF Archives and Special Collections]] |date=July 17, 2013 |accessdate=November 16, 2016 }}</ref> The following week, with Callen, Berkowitz, Felson and Turner,<ref name="How to Survive a Plague p115–6"/> he met with [[Margaret Heckler]], [[United States Secretary of Health and Human Services|Secretary of Health and Human Services]] in the [[Presidency of Ronald Reagan|Reagan administration]].<ref name="How to Survive a Plague p115–6"/> They found Heckler to be receptive to suggestions and, when Campbell pushed the issue of delays in people with AIDS's claims for [[Social Security (United States)|Social Security]], she promised to raise it with her counterpart at the [[Social Security Administration]].<ref name="How to Survive a Plague p115–6"/>
At the first Clinical Nursing Conference on AIDS, in [[Washington, D.C.]], on October 7, 1983, Campbell presented a [[poster session]], "dressed for the part" in white pants and a [[lab coat]].<ref name="How to Survive a Plague p115–6"/><ref name="UCSF A&SC"/> The poster session was designed to help clinicians and nurses understand the message of the Denver Principles, about respect for people with AIDS, rather than considering them as "victims."<ref name="How to Survive a Plague p115–6"/><ref name="UCSF A&SC"/> While at the conference, he attended a talk by an [[infection control]] nurse at the [[National Institutes of Health]] where he discovered the agency's "maximum awareness" policy recommended the use of [[electric green]] "AIDS Precaution" tags on AIDS patients' rooms, blood tubes and laundry.<ref name="How to Survive a Plague p115–6"/> With Artie Felson, he shouted his disgust at the "creepy" policy from the back of the room<ref name="How to Survive a Plague p115–6"/> and arranged an impromptu meeting of the National Association of People With AIDS, where they decided to pay visit to Heckler at her [[Bethesda, Maryland|Bethesda]] office.<ref name="How to Survive a Plague p115–6"/> They spoke with Shelley Lengel, a spokesperson for the new National AIDS Helpline, however Lengel did not call them back with further information about the policy.<ref name="How to Survive a Plague p115–6"/>
In January 1984, when [[Dan White]], the [[Moscone–Milk assassinations|assassin]] of gay San Francisco Supervisor [[Harvey Milk]] and Mayor [[George Moscone]], was due to be paroled, Campbell and Hilliard stood outside [[Soledad State Prison]].<ref name="BAR obit 1984-08-23"/> As White had been transported to Los Angeles for fear of retributive attacks,<ref name="WaPo: Dan White">{{cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/lifestyle/1985/10/23/dan-white-and-his-citys-tragedy/aa148db5-c915-4b24-bcae-d24435fea11f/ |title=Dan White and His City's Tragedy |author=Cynthia Gorney |work=[[The Washington Post]] |date=October 23, 1985 |accessdate=November 14, 2016 }}</ref><ref name="UPI: Dan White">{{cite news |url=http://www.upi.com/Archives/1983/12/31/Officials-fear-for-paroled-assassins-life/2097441694800/ |title=Officials fear for paroled assassin's life |author=Susan Goldfarb |agency=[[United Press International]] |date=December 31, 1983 |accessdate=November 14, 2016 }}</ref><ref name="LA Times: Dan White">{{cite news |url=http://articles.latimes.com/1985-10-25/local/me-14269_1_dan-white |title=Parole agent recalls lonely Encino exile of Dan White |author=Allan Jalon |work=[[Los Angeles Times]] |date=October 25, 1985 |accessdate=November 14, 2016 }}</ref> attendant media had little to cover beyond Campbell with a sign reading "Dan White's homophobia is more deadly than AIDS,"<ref name="BAR obit 1984-08-23"/> bringing further national attention to the health crisis.<ref name="BAR obit 1984-08-23"/>
Later that year, Campbell traveled with [[Angie Lewis]] to [[New Orleans]] for the annual convention of the [[American Nursing Association]] in June, where they gave a 45-minute or hour-long presentation — possibly a [[plenary session]] — about AIDS and HIV, having been invited at the last minute; Lewis suggested this may have been because the ANA were unsure about hosting the session.<ref>Interview with [[Angie Lewis]], nurse educator in the San Francisco AIDS epidemic, on June 29, 1995, by Sally Smith Hughes — in {{cite book |url=https://archive.org/stream/aidsepidemicsf02bancrich#page/134 |title=The AIDS Epidemic in San Francisco: The Response of the Nursing Profession, 1981–1984, volume II |series=The San Francisco AIDS Oral History Series |publisher=Regional Oral History Office, The Bancroft Library, [[University of California, Berkeley]] |year=1999 |pages=135–36 }}</ref>
Campbell gave one of his last speeches at the National March for Lesbian and Gay Rights when the [[1984 Democratic National Convention]] was held in San Francisco in July.<ref name="DNC YouTube"/> He was introduced as a [[feminism|feminist]], a [[voter registration in the United States#Party affiliation|registered]] [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democrat]] and a Person With AIDS; he had served as a board director of the National AIDS Foundation and on the steering committee of the Federation of AIDS-related Organizations, founded the National Association of People With AIDS and testified in front of [[United States congressional committee|Congressional subcommittees]].<ref name="DNC YouTube"/> Campbell told the crowd that he had hugged his boyfriend on the cover of ''Newsweek'', and then kissed Hilliard on stage, "to show Middle America that gay love is beautiful," criticising the [[Christian right]] for using scripture to justify their [[homophobia]].<ref name="DNC YouTube"/> After criticising the lack of progress being made by the Reagan administration, he held 15 seconds of silence for the 2,000 who had died of AIDS at that point "and [for] those who will die before this is over," before laying out a series of concerns for politicians to address — including increased funding for both research and support services and a warning of the potential for discrimination with the advent of a [[diagnosis of HIV/AIDS|test for HTLV-3]] (now known as HIV) — and appealing to all candidates in the [[United States elections, 1984|upcoming elections]] to meet with people with AIDS.<ref name="DNC YouTube"/>
Two weeks later, Campbell appeared on ''[[CBS Evening News]]'' in a live satellite interview with [[Dan Rather]].<ref name="Inglis"/> While the rumors and fear of AIDS had reached a mainstream audience, the facts had not yet, so Campbell was placed in a glass booth, with technicians refusing to come near him to wire up microphones for the interview.<ref name="Inglis"/>
== Death and legacy == [[File:Aids Quilt.jpg|thumb|[[NAMES Project AIDS Memorial Quilt]] in front of the [[Washington Monument]]]] A few days after the DNC speech, another case of shingles left scars across his head;<ref name="How to Survive a Plague p153–4"/> within weeks he was hospitalized with [[cryptosporidiosis]]<ref name="BAR obit 1984-08-16"/><ref name="Shilts PT575"/> and subsequently [[cryptococcal meningitis]].<ref name="How to Survive a Plague p153–4"/> At noon on August 15, 1984,<ref name="How to Survive a Plague p153–4"/> exactly a month after his DNC speech and after 2 days on [[life support]] in [[intensive care]],<ref name="BAR obit 1984-08-16"/> Campbell died at [[San Francisco General Hospital]]<ref name="How to Survive a Plague p153–4"/> when his [[blood pressure]] dropped rapidly.<ref name="How to Survive a Plague p153–4"/> His parents and his partner Bobby Hilliard were by his side.<ref name="How to Survive a Plague p153–4"/> Campbell was 32 years old<ref name="How to Survive a Plague p153–4"/> and had lived for over 3½ years with what was, by then, called AIDS.
Two days later, the city closed Castro Street for Campbell's [[funeral cortège]],<ref name="BAR obit 1984-08-23"/><ref name="How to Survive a Plague p153–4"/> where 1,000 people gathered to remember Campbell.<ref name="BAR obit 1984-08-23"/> A "reverential chant" by the [[Sisters of Perpetual Indulgence]] was followed by several speeches, including Conant and Hilliard as well as Campbell's parents and local performers (including [[Lea DeLaria]] and [[Holly Near]])<ref name="How to Survive a Plague p153–4"/> and an audio recording of [[Paul Boneberg]] introducing Campbell at the National March for Lesbian and Gay Rights a month earlier.<ref name="BAR obit 1984-08-23"/> In his August 23 obituary in the ''Bay Area Reporter'', Allen White described the event as "exactly what should be expected to remember a hero in a crisis."<ref name="BAR obit 1984-08-23"/> ''The Gay Life'' radio show on [[KSAN (FM)|KSAN-FM]], presented by Randy Alfred, Campbell's editor at the ''Sentinel'', covered his memorial across two weeks, on September 16 and 23, 1984.<ref name="The Gay Life 1984-09-16/23">{{cite web |url=http://www.oac.cdlib.org/findaid/ark:/13030/kt0w10244m/entire_text/#c02-1.3.11.3.253 |title=Reel 247, Box 23 (''The Gay Life'' September 16, 1984) and Reel 248, Box 23 (''The Gay Life'' September 23, 1984) |work=Randy Alfred subject files and sound recordings (collection 1991-24) |publisher=[[GLBT Historical Society]] }}</ref> His body was taken back to [[Washington (state)|Washington state]] and interred at New Tacoma Cemetery in [[Tacoma, Washington|Tacoma]]. Campbell had kept a journal throughout his life; Angie Lewis arranged for the journal to be donated to the [[University of California, San Francisco Archives and Special Collections|UCSF Archives and Special Collections]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.oac.cdlib.org/findaid/ark:/13030/kt5000297s/entire_text/ |title=Finding Aid to the Angie Lewis Papers, 1980–1991 (MSS 96-31) |author=Julia Bazar |publisher=[[University of California, San Francisco Archives and Special Collections|UCSF Archives and Special Collections]] |date=2007 |accessdate=November 17, 2016 }}</ref>
The 1985 [[San Francisco Pride|Lesbian/Gay Freedom Day Parade]] was dedicated to Campbell,<ref name="Inglis"/><ref name="Shilts PT138–39"/><ref name="SF Pride Guide 1985">{{cite web |url=https://www.flickr.com/photos/116332530@N03/13988185518/ |title=San Francisco Pride Guide Dedication |via=Jennah Feeley on [[Flickr]] |accessdate=November 14, 2016 }}</ref> "for the work he did as a Person With AIDS, and as a symbol for all of us who continue to fight against the threat that AIDS poses to our survival."<ref name="SF Pride Guide 1985"/> In 2015, the group "Let's Kick ASS—AIDS Survivor Syndrome" were looking to have a [[commemorative plaque]] erected at the site of the Star Pharmacy (now a [[Walgreens]]), where Campbell first put up images of his KS lesions.<ref name="Star Pharmacy Plaque"/> {{As of|2016|post=,}} Bobbi Campbell is memorialized on 4 separate panels of the [[NAMES Project AIDS Memorial Quilt]].<ref name="Quilt search">{{cite web |url=http://www.aidsquilt.org/view-the-quilt/search-the-quilt |title=Search the quilt |publisher=[[NAMES Project AIDS Memorial Quilt]] |accessdate=November 14, 2016 }}</ref>
In the 1993 [[docudrama]] [[Television film|TV movie]] ''[[And the Band Played On (film)|And the Band Played On]]'', adapted from [[Randy Shilts]]'s [[And the Band Played On|book of the same name]] about the early days of the AIDS crisis, Campbell was played by [[Donal Logue]]. Campbell was also portrayed by [[Kevin McHale (actor)|Kevin McHale]] in the 2017 docudrama [[miniseries]] ''[[When We Rise]]'' written by [[Dustin Lance Black]] to chronicle the [[LGBT social movements|gay rights movement]].<ref name="THR: When We Rise">{{cite news |url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/live-feed/abcs-gay-rights-mini-enlists-887779 |title=ABC's gay rights mini enlists Michael K. Williams, sets all-star guest cast |author=Lesley Goldberg |work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]] |date=April 26, 2016 |accessdate=November 15, 2016 }}</ref> The name "Bobbi Campbell" and the names of several other key figures of the time were featured in the [[American Mock Trial Association]]'s 2007–08 National Case Problem,<ref name="American Mock Trial Association">{{cite web |url=http://www.collegemocktrial.org/resources/case-materials/case-materials-access/ |title=Past Case Materials |publisher=[[American Mock Trial Association]] |date= |accessdate=November 18, 2016 }}</ref> albeit in a fictional case, unrelated to Campbell's life.<ref name="American Mock Trial Association"/><ref name="Georgetown Mock Trial Team">{{cite web |url=https://georgetownmocktrial.files.wordpress.com/2011/06/winter-2007.pdf |title=American Mock Trial Association 2007–2008 Case |work=Winter Newsletter |publisher=[[Georgetown University]] Mock Trial Team |date=January 28, 2008 |accessdate=October 7, 2017 |format=PDF }}</ref>
